title: Al-Baggara
text:
Al-Baggara or Bakara (, ' or ') is an <a href="Arab">Arab</a> tribe of the <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates</a> tribes spread widely between <a href="Syria">Syria</a>, <a href="Jordan">Jordan</a> and <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. The tribe was named by the name of their grandfather, <a href="Imam%20Muhammad%20al-Baqir">Imam Muhammad al-Baqir</a>, one of the grandsons of the faithful <a href="Ali%20ibn%20Abi%20Talib">Ali ibn Abi Talib</a>.
The Baggara tribe is considered the largest Syrian tribe. Its men were known for their patriotism and strength; they fought the <a href="French%20colonization">French colonization</a> in immortal exploits and were known for their generosity.
Baggara tribespeople In Syria mainly live west of <a href="Deir%20al-Zour">Deir al-Zour</a> city, ranging from the northern banks of the Euphrates to the <a href="Raqqa">Raqqa</a> provincial border, in villages from Al-Husseiniyah to Mahamidah, where the Baggara's chiefdom family lives, to <a href="Al-Kasrah">al-Kasrat</a>, al-Kubar/Jazrat al-Boshams, and Jazra Al-Milaj, spanning a distance of some 80 km.
East of Deir al-Zour, the Baggara live in smaller numbers in the villages of Meratt, <a href="Khasham">Khusham</a>, and Jadid Baggara; sources suggest a total of approximately 100,000 Baggara live in these areas east and west of the city. Although accurate figures are not available, a large number of people of Baggara lineage have integrated into Deir al-Zour city, some say a full one-third of the city's residents have roots in the tribe, Prominent Baggara families there are Fadel Al-Aboud, Al-Ayesh, Al-Ayyash, where they had a major role in the political leadership of the city of Deir al-Zour.
Other regions where the Baggara lives include <a href="Hasaka">Hasaka</a> province, in an area known as Baggara Al-Jabal (Baggara Mountain), <a href="Raqqa">Raqqa</a> the city of <a href="Aleppo">Aleppo</a> and other northern towns, and <a href="Idlib">Idlib</a>. Some reports indicate that their number in Syria is around 1.2 million.
Structure.
The tribe encompasses the following clans, mostly in Deir al-Zour province but also in <a href="Hasaka">Hasaka</a>, <a href="Raqqa">Raqqa</a>, and <a href="Aleppo">Aleppo</a>:
Economy.
Most Baggara tribespeoples are farmers who cultivate fruit trees and vegetables. Some of them were engaged in business and became prominent businessmen in Syria. Many Baggara tribespeople work for the <a href="Syrian%20government">Syrian government</a>, mainly in <a href="Deir%20al-Zour">Deir al-Zour</a>, after which they return home to their surrounding suburbs or villages, and Large numbers of Baggara also work in <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a> and the <a href="Arab%20States%20of%20the%20Persian%20Gulf">Persian Gulf states</a>.
Politics.
Baggara tribespeople who live in Deir al-Zour city has a long political history, Where some of the families of the tribe as Fadel Al-Aboud, Al-Ayesh, Al-Ayyash from the Abdulkarim clan led the city of Deir al-Zour since the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> era and continued during the occupation of English and <a href="French%20Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">French</a>. Some of the tribe leaders fought <a href="French%20Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">French</a> and English colonialism, such as the leader <a href="Ayyash%20Al-Haj">Ayyash Al-Haj</a>, who was exiled by the <a href="French%20Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">French authorities</a> with his family to the city of <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a> in 1925 and executed some of his sons after being accused of preparing a revolution in <a href="Deir%20el-Zour">Deir el-Zour</a> to relieve pressure on the area of <a href="Jabal%20al-Arab">Jabal al-Arab</a> during the <a href="Great%20Syrian%20Revolution">Great Syrian Revolution</a> in 1925.
After the formation of the Syrian state, Minister Mohamed Al-Ayesh emerged as the first minister in the Eastern Province and continued for many years and was known as a man of ministries.
In the modern era, Baggara tribespeople supported the <a href="Baath%20Arab%20Socialist%20Party">Baath</a> and Nasserist parties, One tribesman from the Abdulkarim clan, Yassin Al-Hafiz (1930–78), noted for his intellectualism, served as an architect of <a href="Baath%20party%20ideology">Baath party ideology</a>. A large number of tribespeople belong to the Baath wings in both <a href="Syria">Syria</a> and <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>, and The Baggara tribe also includes members of the <a href="Communist%20Party">Communist Party</a>.
Many of Baggara tribespeople joined the <a href="Baath%20Party%20%28Syria%29">Baath Party</a> primarily for benefits and government employment, But many quickly turned against the regime and joined the 2011 uprising; during this period of anti-Assad activism, <a href="Sheikh">Sheikh</a> Nawaf Ragheb Al-Bashir delivered anti-regime speeches attended by tribespeople who traveled to <a href="Deir%20al-Zour">Deir al-Zour</a> from their nearby <a href="villages">villages</a>. Originally, Sheikh Nawaf joined the Party of Socialist Unitarians and called for <a href="pan-Arabism">pan-Arabism</a>; then he supported <a href="Iran">Iran</a>’s <a href="Shia">Shia</a> ideology and the <a href="Shia">Shia</a> <a href="coalition">coalition</a>
in <a href="Syria">Syria</a>.
Celebrities of Tribe.
Fadel Al-Aboud.
Fadel Aboud Al-Hassan or Haj Fadel Al-Aboud, a <a href="Syrians">Syrian</a> leader and head of the <a href="Haj%20Fadel%20Government">Haj Fadel Government</a> in eastern <a href="Syria">Syria</a> after the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottomans</a> left the region in 1918.
<a href="Fadel%20Al-Aboud">Al-Hassan</a> was born in Deir al-Zour in 1872 for Al-Hassan family from the Abo Obaid <a href="clan">clan</a> from Al-Baggara <a href="tribe">tribe</a>.
<a href="Fadel%20Al-Aboud">Al-Hassan</a> was of high social standing in Deir al-Zour, which enabled him to take over the leadership of his father, Aboud Hassan. Al-Hassan worked in trade and had extensive commercial relations with <a href="Turkic%20peoples">Turkish</a> merchants and <a href="Aleppo">Halbians</a> and with his cousins Najjar and Tayfur in the city of <a href="Hama">Hama</a>.
When the trouble broke out in the city of Deir al-Zour after the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottomans</a> left on 6 November 1918, people began looting and stealing from each other across the area, so it was necessary to have a strong authority for protecting the city and its people, and that led Al-Hassan who was the mayor to form his first government in the city and asking all <a href="tribal">tribal</a> leaders in the <a href="villages">villages</a> and surrounding districts to support him and pledge allegiance to him. One of this government's priorities was maintaining the security and running the affairs of the city. This government knew as the "government of Haj Fadel."
The government continued until the arrival of Sharif Nasser, the cousin of Prince <a href="Faisal%20bin%20Hussein">Faisal Bin Al-Hussein</a>, on 1 December 1918, and Mari Basha Al-Mallah on 7 December 1918.
After the <a href="Battle%20of%20Maysalun">Battle of Maysalun</a> on 24 July 1920 and occupation of <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a> by <a href="French%20Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">French forces</a>, The city of <a href="Deir%20Ezzor">Deir Ezzor</a> was in a state of chaos and insecurity, which prompted Al-Hassan to form his second government, Which has done excellent services in protecting the city and maintaining the security of its people despite its limited capabilities.
This government continued its work until 23 November 1920, when it was dissolved by the <a href="French%20Mandate%20for%20Syria%20and%20the%20Lebanon">French occupation</a> authorities.
Al-Hassan represented the <a href="Euphrates">Euphrates</a> region at the <a href="Syrian%20National%20Congress">Syrian National Congress</a> held in late June 1919, which proclaimed the independence of <a href="Syria">Syria</a> and establishment of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Syria">Syrian Arab Kingdom</a> on 8 March 1920, and appointed <a href="Faisal%20bin%20Hussein">Faisal bin Sharif Hussein</a> as a king. Al-Hassan participated in the coronation of <a href="Faisal%20bin%20Hussein">Faisal</a> as king of <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a> on 23 August 1921 and supported his <a href="inauguration">inauguration</a>.
Al-Hassan died in 1936 in Deir al-Zour and was buried there. His sons continued his political work. His son, Dr. Badri Fadel Aboud, became the <a href="Minister%20of%20Health">Minister of Health</a> in the government of <a href="Said%20al-Ghazzi">Said Al-Ghazi</a> in 1955, under the presidency of President <a href="Shukri%20al-Quwatli">Shukri al-Quwatli</a>. He was the first <a href="Minister%20of%20Health">Minister of Health</a> from Deir al-Zour.
Ayyash Al-Haj.
Ayyash Al-Haj Hussein Al-Jassim, a <a href="Syrian">Syrian</a> leader from Deir al-Zour city, began the armed struggle against the <a href="French%20colonization">French colonizer</a> in <a href="governorate">governorate</a> of Deir al-Zour in 1925 coinciding with the outbreak of the <a href="Great%20Syrian%20Revolution">Great Syrian Revolution</a> in <a href="Jabal%20al-Arab">Jabal al-Arab</a> and <a href="Ghouta">Ghouta</a> of <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a>. He was sentenced by the French to exile to <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a> city with his family after they were convicted of planning and carrying out several military operations against the <a href="French%20forces">French forces</a>, the latest was in "<a href="The%20epic%20of%20Ain%20Albu%20Gomaa">Ain Albu Gomaa</a>". They also sentenced his eldest son Mohammed 20 years in prison on the <a href="Arwad">island of Arwad</a>, and executed his son Mahmoud by shooting with a number of other <a href="revolutionaries">revolutionaries</a>.
<a href="Ayyash%20Al-Haj">Ayyash</a> was born in <a href="Deir%20al-Zour">Deir al-Zour</a> in 1864 for Al-Haj family from the Abo Obaid <a href="clan">clan</a> from Al-Baggara <a href="tribe">tribe</a>., He grew up in a national family that contributed to the struggle against the <a href="colonizer">colonizer</a>s throughout history, Therefore, Ayyash was liking his city and his homeland, and a lover of its material and immaterial traditions, and that is why he devoted most of his life to the service and protection of his city. When the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottomans</a> left <a href="Deir%20ez-Zor">Deir ez-Zor</a>, Ayyash Al-Haj contributed to protecting the people of <a href="Deir%20ez-Zor">Deir ez-Zor</a> from the chaos and the absence of security left by the absence of the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman</a> authority. He formed a local government known as <a href="Haj%20Fadel%20Government">Haj Fadel Government</a> with the dignitaries of <a href="Deir%20ez-Zor">Deir ez-Zor</a>, headed by his cousin from the Abu Obaid <a href="clan">clan</a>, <a href="Fadel%20Al-Aboud">Fadel Al-Aboud</a> in 1918.
He established a national army from the people of the city with Mr. Omar Al-'Abd Al-'Aziz and Mr. Khalaf Al-'Abd Al-Hamid to counter the <a href="invasion">invasion</a> of the <a href="English%20Army">English</a> and clashed with them at the site of <a href="Al-Salihiyah%2C%20Deir%20ez-Zor%20Governorate">Salhiya</a> in 1919.
<a href="Ayyash%20Al-Haj">Ayyash Al-Haj</a> also contributed to resolving many <a href="Group%20conflict">conflict</a>s and <a href="revolutions">revolutions</a> between the people of <a href="Deir%20ez-Zor">Deir ez-Zor</a> and between them and the people of the countryside due to his close ties with Al-Baggara <a href="tribe">tribe</a>s, his cousins and close friends of the Albu Saraya <a href="clan">clan</a>, who later participated with his sons in the formation of armed revolutionary groups against the <a href="French%20Armed%20Forces">French forces</a>.
The French sentenced him to exile in the city of <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a> with his family members in 1925; they also sentenced his eldest son Mohammad to 20 years' imprisonment and executed his son Mahmoud by firing squad, after being convicted of planning and carrying out several military operations against <a href="French%20Armed%20Forces">French forces</a> in Syria, the most recent of which was the epic of Ain Bou Juma in 1925.
Ayyash and his family left to their exile in the city of <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a> where the people of the city embraced him and were respected him for their struggle and virtues.
Shortly after Ayyash Al-Haj family's living in <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a>, The French authorities assassinated Ayyash Al-Haj in a café outside the city by <a href="poisoning">poisoning</a> his coffee, and prevented the transfer of his body to <a href="Deir%20ez-Zor">Deir Ezzor</a> city for reasons of public security, He was buried in <a href="Jableh">Jableh</a> in the cemetery of Sultan <a href="Ibrahim%20ibn%20Adham">Ibrahim ibn Adham</a> Mosque where the absent prayers held for the spirit of this martyr <a href="Mujahideen">mujahid</a> in all the Syrian cities.
